emphasis.docTitle: Overview of the nematode fauna of Pakistan

subSection.paragraph: F. Shahina † , K. Nasira , K. Firoza and Y. I. Erum

paragraph.docAuthorAffiliation: National Nematological Research Centre , University of Karachi , Karachi-75270 , Pakistan

subSection.paragraph: This research publication provides a comprehensive indexed resource of plant parasitic, soil, marine and entomopathogenic nematode species described and reported during last sixty nine years (1952-2019) from Pakistan. The information compiled in this paper came gradually from many and diverse sources. It is the product of the efforts of several authors who contributed to gather knowledge on the biological diversity through systematics and faunistic studies. Information published in different scientific journals, newsletters, reports, book chapters, books booklets and proceedings have been considered. Those records contained in abstracts of conferences/ congresses, doctoral theses were not included. A total of 749 species belonging to 261 genera of 81 subfamiles, 85 families of 24 Superfamiles, 19 suborders of 12 orders have been described and reported so far from Pakistan in which 232 species are new to science. The paper includes i) new nematode species described from Pakistan in chronological order; ii) species of plant parasitic nematodes; iii) species of free-living soil nematodes; iv) species of marine nematodes; v) species of entomopathogenic nematodes all in alphabetical order and vi) taxonomic position of the all nematode species of Pakistan.
Keywords: Nematode fauna, systematics, new and known species, Pakistan.

N ematology is one of the most dynamic and exciting discipline in the agricultural science. The development of nematology is largely attributed to the discovery of the importance of nematodes in agricultural ecosystems and their impact on society. The economic stability of the country depends upon the performance of the agriculture sectors, it is therefore extremely important that the agriculture sector perform its role of sustenance of national economy. In an agriculture country like Pakistan, the plant parasitic nematode besides other pest and disease causing organisms, have been recognized as one of the greatest threat to crop production. Nematodes are one of the most abundant, highly diversified and ecologically significant groups with wide host range and wide geographical distribution. They may be free-living in marine and fresh water, soil inhabiting and as parasites on all kinds of plants.
Inspite of these, the subject of nematology remained neglected and given very little importance by the academic institutions and agriculturists of the country.

According to the latest information available the 232 new nematode species were recorded in Pakistan so far. The paper provides comprehensive lists of 749 species of all nematode groups belonging to 261 genera, 85 families and 12 orders ( Fig. 1 ), reported during the last six decades since the first contribution of Sattar & Hafiz (1952) who reported
Anguina tritici
from D.G. Khan, Muzaffargarh and Jhang areas of Pakistan. The taxonomic positions of species also incorporated regarding the nematode fauna of Pakistan.
Published by Pakistan Society of Nematologists

Classification of plant parasitic, soil, marine and entomopathogenic nematodes was based on the systematics provided by various groups experts. Siddiqi (2000) book was followed for the higher categories and synonymy for the order Tylenchida Thorne, 1949 , but some other nomenclatorial changes have been introduced; in general, Aphelenchida Siddiqi, 1980 systematics was followed, given by Hunt (1993) . Jairajpuri & Ahmad (1992) , classification for the order Dorylaimida Pearse, 1942 was followed. In general, the nomenclature provided by Ahmed & Jairajpuri, (2010) for the taxa of Mononchida Jairajpuri, 1969 , has been accepted for higher categories and synomyms in present details.

Andrassy’s (2005 ; 2007 ) classification is followed in the higher categories for the taxa belonging to the order Rabditida Chitwood, 1933 ; Diplogastrida Maggenti, 1981; Triplonchida Cobb, 1920 ; Chromadorida Filipjev, 1929 ; Enoplida Filipjev, 1929 ; Monhysterida Filipjev, 1929 whereas Lorenzen (1981) , Platt & Warwick (1983 , 1988 ) and Somerfield et al., 1998 contributions for the systematics of Enoplida, Filipjev, 1929 ; Chromadorida Filipjev, 1929 ; Monhysterida Filipjev, 1929 ; Araeolaimida De Coninck & Schuurmans-Stekhoven, 1933 , Plectida Malakhov, 1982 was also considered but recent nomenclatorial changes were also introduced. In systematics and characterization of number of species and genera, Eyualem-Abebe et al ., (2006) was also taken under consideration.
